units.summary: Native American society before European Contact, European exploration in the New World, Exploration in the new World

events.title: Columbus arrives in the New World
events.description: Sparks flow of trade between old and new world. Stimulates food production and growth. Spain becomes colonial power in the Americas

units.summary: Colonies established in the New World by the Spanish, French, Dutch, and British
American Revolution, the events that led up to it, and the formation of the United States

presidents.name: George Washington
presidents.description: First President of the United States

presidents.name: John Adams
presidents.description: Foreign Affairs with France

events.title: Seven Years' War/French and Indian War
events.description: global conflict between France and Great Britain; caused Britain to go double debt and increase taxes on colonists

events.title: Taxation without Representation
events.description: Colonial people didn't want the taxation without representation; British claims virtual representation that they represented everyone

events.title: Sugar Act
events.description: first British law to tax sugar and molasses imported into American colonies

events.title: Currency Act
events.description: prohibited American colonies from issuing their own currency

events.title: Quartering Act
events.description: British law that required American colonies to provide housing and provisions to British soldiers

events.title: Stamp Act
events.description: after colonists got rid of Sugar Act, parliament taxed all papers; repealed in 1766 as many commended the colonists for resisting a tax passed when not represented

events.title: Declaratory Act
events.description: repeal of the Stamp Act made Parliament pass an act on the same day that stated Parliament could make laws binding the American colonies 'in all cases whatsoever'

events.title: Boston Tea Party
events.description: American political and mercantile protest against tax on tea and 'taxation without representation'

events.title: Thomas Paine's Common Sense
events.description: pamphlet written by Thomas Paine advocating for independence from Great Britain in the colonies; based heavily on enlightenment ideals

events.title: Declaration of Independence
events.description: Articulated the principle of individual liberty and government's responsibility to serve the government's economy

events.title: American Revolutionary War
events.description: despite Britain's military and financial advantages, the American Patriots won the Revolutionary War and gained independence

events.title: Articles of Confederation
events.description: the first constitution of the United States of America, failed due to weak federal government; all government power in legislative, but weak, as many wanted weak government contrasting from strong British power

events.title: Shays' Rebellion
events.description: rebellion over debt; displayed weakness of government and inability to have army for domestic and international purposes

events.title: Constitutional Convention
events.description: to help rectify the weakness of the Articles of Confederation; the Great Compromise (Connecticut Compromise): Bicameral legislation; 3/5s Compromise: 3/5s of slave population counted towards population

events.title: Federalism
events.description: sharing of power between state and government;

events.title: Judiciary Act of 1789
events.description: Established courts below the Supreme Court

events.title: French Revolution
events.description: Social and political upheaval in France that allowed the U.S. to expand its territory

events.title: Bill of Rights is ratified
events.description: First ten amendments to the Constitution: (1) Freedom of speech, press, religion, assembly, and petition; (2) Right to bear arms; (3) No quartering of soldiers; (4) No unreasonable search and seizure; (5) Due process of law; (6) Right to a speedy trial; (7) Right to a jury trial in civil cases; (8) No cruel and unusual punishment; (9) Rights not enumerated in the Constitution are still protected; (10) Powers not given to the federal government are reserved for the states

events.title: Republican Motherhood
events.description: idea that women had vital role in shaping nation by raising virtuous citizens

events.title: First Bank of the United States is established
events.description: Federal Bank proposed by Alexander Hamilton to stabilize the economy and establish credit; to have all the states debts to one national debt, viewed as a control of power by opponents; helped by Elastic Clause in the Constitution

events.title: Hamilton (Fed) vs Jefferson (Dem-Rep)
events.description: Hamilton pushed for national debt, interest of rich, home manufacturing, strong executive, weak state government, and alliance with Britain; Jefferson pushed for government run by people, strong state governments, and was against a standing army

events.title: Whiskey Rebellion
events.description: Farmers in Pennsylvania rebelled against excise tax on whiskey; Washington sent troops to put down rebellion, expressing power of the new government; mainly supported by Federalists

events.title: Jay Treaty
events.description: Settle disputes between U.S. and Britain over trade and territory; U.S. will not trade with ports opened during war time that were closed during peace time, British will leave forts (not really) and allow U.S. trade in Asia

events.title: Washington's Farewell Address
events.description: Advised for strong central government, foreign neutrality, and warns against factions

events.title: John Adams elected, Jefferson as VP
events.description: George Washington steps down after two terms

events.title: XYZ Affair
events.description: France attacks American Ships and makes unreasonable demandsâ€”no money, no war

events.title: Alien and Sedition Acts
events.description: illegal to publish anything against government or president

events.title: Virginia and Kentucky Resolutions
events.description: gave states the right to nullify if deemed unconstitutional (ie. Alien and Sedition Acts)

events.title: Fries Uprising
events.description: opposed federal tax on property but was put down

events.title: Logan Act
events.description: George Logan attempts to negotiate with France, but deemed that a citizen cannot represent the government

events.title: Convention of 1800
events.description: Hamilton negotiated with France, ended alliance with France during revolution, but extended "most-favored" trading status

units.summary: Political parties and foreign policies, debates about federal power, and the cultural and economic development of early America

presidents.name: Thomas Jefferson
presidents.description: argument between political parties, Supreme Court establishes its role, and U.S. expands territorial holdings

presidents.name: James Madison
presidents.description: led the nation during the War of 1812 and held commitment to civil liberties

presidents.name: James Monroe
presidents.description: Beginning of Era of Good Feelings/Era of Common Man

presidents.name: John Quincy Adams
presidents.description: Tariffs and debates on slavery

presidents.name: Andrew Jackson
presidents.description: Tariffs and banks

presidents.name: Martin Van Buren
presidents.description: Overspeculation of land and anti-bank

presidents.name: William Henry Harrison
presidents.description: Beginning of Antebellum Period, died

presidents.name: John Tyler
presidents.description: Did some stuff

presidents.name: James K. Polk
presidents.description: Admission of new states

events.title: Jefferson elected
events.description: government changes from Federalist to Democratic-Republican

events.title: Strict interpretation of the Constitution
events.description: Federalists supported loose interpretation of the Constitution; Democratic-Republicans supported strict interpretation of the Constitution to limit federal authority

events.title: Louisiana Purchase
events.description: Purchased most of middle from France while France was in revolution; Federalists opposed, established loose construction of the Constitution

events.title: Marbury v. Madison
events.description: Supreme Court declares parts of Judiciary Act of 1789 unconstitutional; Supreme Court could declare laws unconstitutional; powers of Court only given in Constitution

events.title: New Jersey ends slavery
events.description: leads to gradual emancipation of Northern states

events.title: Lewis and Clark Expedition
events.description: Explored new territory after Louisiana Purchase; mapped uncharted land, brought details of Native Americans, and documented over 300 new species of animals and plants

events.title: Tripoli War ends
events.description: War between US and North African state of Tripoli; US refused to pay in 1801 which led to US ships being captured

events.title: First Steamboat
events.description: Robert Fulton builds first steamboat, reducing travel time significantly, stimulating economy through transportation of goods, and contributed to expansion westward

events.title: Chesapeake Affair
events.description: US Ship Leopard sunk by British for refusal to be searched; provoked wave of nationalism and anti-British sentiment

events.title: Embargo Act
events.description: stopped trade exports to all foreign nations, put measures against impressment, placed import restrictions on Great Britain; led to economic hardship and made many resort to smuggling goods

events.title: African Slave Trade ends
events.description: transatlantic slave-trade abolished in the United States, however slaving continued to be legal

events.title: Madison elected
events.description: Madison had previously served as Secretary of States

events.title: Nonintercourse Act
events.description: resumes all trade barred during Embargo Act except with France and Britain

events.title: Fletcher v. Pack
events.description: action of a state can be declared unconstitutional

events.title: Charter for Bank of U.S. rejected
events.description: main debate between pro-bank Federalists and anti-centralized power Democratic-Republicans; many believed it favored elites

events.title: Battle of Tippecanoe
events.description: battle between Indian Tecumseh, helped by the British, and Americans led by Harrison; destroyed hope for large Indian Confederacy

events.title: War Hawks
events.description: members of congress who pushed for war against Britain leading up to the War of 1812

events.title: The War of 1812
events.description: fought between U.S. and Great Britain; affirmed American independence from British influence, surge in nationalism; Federalists opposed the war, leading to decline in Federalist Party post-war

events.title: Treaty of Ghent
events.description: ended War of 1812; addressed territory of both parties, did not address trade restrictions and impressment of American sailors; paved way for Era of Good Feelings

events.title: Hartford Convention
events.description: Federalists were against War of 1812 and mercantile practice of Madison; secretly debated and rejected secession; drafted amendments strengthening state over commerce and militia

events.title: Second Bank of the United States created
events.description: created to stabilize economy after War of 1812 by regulating currency and managing federal funds

events.title: First Protective Tariff
events.description: to protect New England manufactures from cheap British manufactured goods

events.title: American Colonization Society founded
events.description: formed over debate of slavery and abolitionism; wanted relocate free blacks to Liberia, although many blacks at the time were born in the United States

events.title: Henry Clay's American System
events.description: to unify American by strengthen national economy through national bank, protective tariffs, and internal improvements, such as roads and canals

events.title: Monroe elected
events.description: marked start of Era of Good Feelings

events.title: Era of Good Feelings
events.description: decline of partisan conflicts; aimed to promote national unity and cooperation, economic growth, and territorial expansion; significant regional tensions between North and South over slavery

events.title: Veto of Bonus Bill
events.description: supplying funds for roads and canals to states; vetoed by Madison, as he believed states should pay for their own improvements

events.title: Rush-Bagot Disarmament
events.description: fishing rights between U.S. and Britain; aimed to limit naval armaments on the Great Lakes and Lake Champlain to de-escalate tensions between the two nations

events.title: Convention of 1818
events.description: set boundary between the Missouri Territory and British North America at the forty-ninth parallel; marked beginning of Anglo-American cooperation

events.title: Transcontinental Treaty/Adams-Onis Treaty
events.description: U.S. acquired Florida from Spain for 5 million, put boundary to Spanish territories, later Texas, New Mexico, and California

events.title: Panic of 1819
events.description: first major financial crisis of the U.S.; widespread economic downturn and bank failures, which led to scrutiny of banking practices and reform of banking system; rise of populism and changing attitudes of government intervention into economy

events.title: McCulloch v Maryland
events.description: federal government had the right to set up a federal bank and the states did not have the power to tax the government

events.title: Dartmouth College v Woodward
events.description: Dartmouth charter as private could not be changed to public by the New Hampshire legislature; established principle of protecting private corporations from state interference

events.title: Missouri Compromise
events.description: admitted Maine as a free state and Missouri as a slave state but no slavery north of Missouri Land Act

events.title: Cumberland Road Bill
events.description: Cumberland Road, or the National Road, was the first federally funded highway; helped in the Market Revolution and facilitated westward expansion; made precedent for federal involvement in infrastructure and future transportation projects

events.title: Monroe Doctrine
events.description: foreign policy statement that warned European nations against colonization and intervention in the Americas and established the Western Hemisphere as the sphere of American influence; set commitment to protecting Latin American nations; established U.S. as a growing global power

events.title: Russo-American Treaty
events.description: outlined boundaries between U.S. and Russian Alaska

events.title: John Q. Adams elected
events.description: defeats Andrew Jackson and Clay; Andrew Jackson received most popular and electoral votes; House elected John Quincy Adams after allegedly striking a deal with Henry Clay who had received the least of the four candidates, sparking accusations of a 'Corrupt Bargain'

events.title: Gibbons v. Ogden
events.description: concluded that interstate trade would be controlled by federal courts

events.title: Erie Canal opens
events.description: first transportation route connecting the Atlantic Ocean and the Great Lakes that did not require over land transportation

events.title: Panama Conference (PAN American)
events.description: established Pan-American Union that dealt with issues concerning Monroe Doctrine

events.title: Tariff of Abominations
events.description: significant tariffs on imported goods and raw materials; greatly opposed by Southern economy

events.title: South Carolina Exposition and Protest
events.description: Calhoun protests for and reaffirms the rights of states to nullify

events.title: Andrew Jackson elected
events.description: Jackson promises to limit executive power, provide internal improvements, and lower debt; appoints 'Kitchen Cabinet' of trusted friends

events.title: Maysville Road Bill Veto
events.description: proposed building a road in Kentucky, but vetoed as Jackson didn't like Clay and Martin Van Buren noted New York and Pennsylvania paid for their transportation with state money; applied strict interpretation of the Constitution

events.title: Webster-Hayne Debates
events.description: Webster (nationalist) and Hayne (states rights) debated on the topic nullification

events.title: Transcendentalism
events.description: emphasized individual intuition, inherent goodness of people, and a deeper connection to nature; promoted self-reliance and questioned social norms

events.title: The Second Great Awakening
events.description: religious revival movement in the early 19th century; included renewed interest in Christianity, increase in church membership, and formation of various new religious denominations; brought early feminism and other reform movements

events.title: Baltimore and Ohio Railroad begins operation
events.description: first common carrier railroad in the U.S. to provide transportation between the East Coast and the Ohio River

events.title: The Liberator begins publication
events.description: abolitionist movement becomes more widespread; served as important part of Boston's Underground Railroad network and reported on fugitive slave cases; the South were highly against, due to their reliance on slaves for economy

events.title: Nat Turner Rebellion
events.description: bloody slave rebellion in Virginia that led to killings of nearly 60 white people; caused black churches to be broken up, Anti-literacy laws to increase, and put harsher restrictions on slaves and blacks

events.title: Cyrus McCormick invents the reaper
events.description: made cutting crops for harvest much more efficient

events.title: The Trial of Tears
events.description: about 60,000 Southern Indians forcefully removed from Oklahoma and sent to designated Indian Territory west of the Mississippi, causing death of many Indians due to disease and starvation

events.title: Tariff of 1832
events.description: to act as a remedy for Tariff of 1828; reduced duties but retained high taxes on imported irons, cottons, and woolens; led to the nullification crisis

events.title: Ordinance of Nullification
events.description: South Carolina refused to accept the tariff as the believed it would set a precedent for congressional legislation for slavery; made it unlawful for federal officials to collect duties in state

events.title: Force Bill
events.description: made in response to the Southern nullification and allowed the president to use force as necessary to enforce tariffs

events.title: Veto of Bank of U.S. recharter
events.description: Jackson vetos recharter just before reelection of 1832, stating it was unconstitutional despite being considered constitutional by the court, placed Federal funds in banks that supported Jackson and state banks

events.title: Agreement with Britain to open West Indies ports
Texas War of Independence
events.description: rebellion by Texas settlers against Mexican rule, leading to establishment of Republic of Texas; 'Lone Star Republic'

events.title: The Gag Rule
events.description: prohibited debate or action on anti-slavery petitions; reflected increasing tensions around slavery

events.title: Specie Circular
events.description: required that western land must be paid with hard currency; caused failure of banks as banks did not have that much hard currency

events.title: Van Buren elected
events.description: successor to Jackson, Martin Van Buren beats Harrison (Whigs) but is 'puppet' of Jackson

events.title: Recognition of Republic of Texas
events.description: one year after Texas declares independence from Mexico

events.title: Oberlin College enrolls first women students
events.description: early steps of feminism movement

events.title: <i>Charles Bridge v. Warren Bridge
events.description: strict interpretation of contract; reversed Dartmouth College v. Woodward

events.title: Panic of 1837
events.description: financial crisis caused by rapid economic growth, speculation of land, and concerns of banks

events.title: Aroostook War
events.description: bloodless boundary disputes between Maine and New Brunswick

events.title: Independent Treasury Systems
events.description: constructs vaults to hold federal money rather than have commercial banks manage funds as response to economic instability

events.title: Harrison elected
events.description: Harrison defeats Van Buren

events.title: Tyler becomes president
events.description: Harrison catches pneumonia and dies

events.title: Independent Treasury Act repealed
events.description: Whigs did not like federal banks and wanted more economic control to people

events.title: Recharter of Bank of the U.S. vetoed
events.description: Tyler vetoes recharter to charter a new National Bank to replace

events.title: Preemption Bill
events.description: to protect rights of 'squatters,' settlers who occupied public lands before they were surveyed and sold by the government, to allow claiming land before it was surveyed

events.title: Tariff Bill of 1842/Black Tariff
events.description: raised tariffs back to how it was in 1832, reversing Compromise Tariff of 1833 to protect American industries from foreign competition

events.title: Dorr Rebellion
events.description: rebellion in Rhode Island against land qualifications needed for voting; put down by Tyler

events.title: Webster-Ashburton Treaty
events.description: resolved border disputes between British North America and the United States; also addressed African slave trade and extradition

events.title: Oregon Trail
events.description: route used to reach Oregon Territory and other westward areas

events.title: Texas Annexation Bill
events.description: allowed annexation of Texas and Florida, leading to annexation of Texas later in the year

units.summary: Manifest Destiny, Mexican-American War, Southern Succession, and the leading to the Civil War

presidents.name: James K. Polk
presidents.description: Admission of new states

presidents.name: Zachary Taylor
presidents.description: Died in office

presidents.name: Millard Fillmore
presidents.description: Truce over battle of slavery

presidents.name: James Buchanan
presidents.description: Beginning of Southern Succession and Civil War

presidents.name: Abraham Lincoln
presidents.description: Led Union through the Civil War

presidents.name: Andrew Johnson
presidents.description: Reconstruction after the Civil War

presidents.name: Ulysses S. Grant
presidents.description: War general turned president

events.title: Polk elected
events.description: Polk (Dem) defeats Clay (Whig) and Birney (Liberty; Anti-slavery)

events.title: Elias Howe invents sewing machine
events.description: revolutionized clothing industry and boosted Northern industrialization during the Industrial Revolution

events.title: Mexican-American War
events.description: stemming from the annexation of Texas, the war represents growing expansionism and forced American's to discuss the issue of slavery

events.title: Slidell Mission
events.description: to negotiate purchase of California and New Mexico; arrival marked with hostility

events.title: Wilmot Proviso
events.description: proposed to ban slavery in any territory acquired from Mexican-American War; never made a law but contributed to the rise of the Free Soil Party and the Republican Party who were against slavery

events.title: Fifty-four Forty or Fight
events.description: a popular slogan used during the Oregon Question; American's wanted the land about 54 degrees and 40 minutes north parallel or would fight Great Britain for the land

events.title: Reestablishment of the Independent Treasury System
events.description: to separate federal government's funds from private banks and manage them through the Treasury instead

events.title: Walker Tariff Act
events.description: lowered import duties in the U.S., aiming to reduce since Black Tariff; led to increase in trade and government revenue

events.title: Polk Doctrine
events.description: resurrection of the Monroe Doctrine concerning the admission of new states into the union

events.title: Obtained Oregon
events.description: for years, Oregon Territory had been joint owned by the U.S. and Britain; major part of Manifest Destiny ideology

events.title: Trist Mission
events.description: negotiates Treaty of Guadelupe Hidalgo to get territory of Arizona, California, Colorado, Nevada, New Mexico, Utah, and Wyoming

events.title: Gold Rush in California
events.description: Gold discovered in Sutter's Mill, California led many to migrate to California in hopes of striking it rich; led to rapid westward migration and political and economic changes

events.title: Seneca Falls Women's Rights Convention
events.description: first women's rights convention aiming for women suffrage

events.title: Taylor elected
events.description: Taylor (Whig) defeats Cass (Dem; father of popular sovereignty) and Van Buren (Free-Soil; abolitionist)

events.title: Fillmore becomes president
events.description: Taylor dies

events.title: Clay's Compromise of 1850
events.description: crafted by three influential statesmen, Henry Clay, Daniel Webster, and Stephen Douglas; passed as five separate bills: California as a free state, strong Fugitive Slave Act, End to slave trade in Washington D.C., Texas/New Mexico boundary settled, popular sovereignty in Utah and New Mexico territories

events.title: Clayton-Bulwer Treaty
events.description: U.S. amd Britain agree to jointly protect the neutrality of a canal in Central America

events.title: Japan opens to US trade
events.description: Commodore Matthew Perry reaches Japan and demands opening of trade to the US

events.title: Pierce elected
events.description: Pierce defeats Scott (Whig)

events.title: Gadsden Purchase
events.description: purchase land from Mexico to build transcontinental railroad and exhibited America's Manifest Destiny

events.title: 'Uncle Tom's Cabin'
events.description: anti-slavery novel written by Harriet Beecher Stowe; helped shape Northern perceptions of African American slavery

events.title: Kansas-Nebraska Act
events.description: repealed the Missouri Compromise and created two new territories that allowed for popular sovereignty; produced a violent uprising known as 'Bleeding Kansas' where proslavery and antislavery activists flooded in to sway the vote

events.title: New England Emigrant Aid Society
events.description: helped people emigrate into Kansas and Nebraska territories

events.title: Bleeding Kansas
events.description: Topeka government (Free Soil) against LeCompton government (slavery) in Kansas to determine slave status of state

events.title: Ostend Manifesto
events.description: America tried to use force to seize Cuba for national security; resulted from debates over slavery, where slaveholders wanted a new territory for expansion of slavery; northerners were outraged by Southerners

events.title: Walker expedition
events.description: Walker raises an army and takes over Nicaragua tp develop a proslavery empire; Pierce recognizes the new government, but Walker was killed by Honduran authorities

events.title: Lawrence Mob Violence
events.description: burned many abolitionist materials

events.title: Pottawatomie Massacre
events.description: John Brown kills four pro-slavery people; John Brown believed that violent action was necessary to combat slavery; ended up further polarizing public opinion about slavery

events.title: Buchanan elected
events.description: Buchanan defeats Fremont (Rep; Free Soil) and Fillmore (Know Nothings)

events.title: Dred Scott decision
events.description: slaves are property that can be taken anywhere; cannot be freed from staying into slave-free state; allowed for slavery in the North and provided Missouri Compromise to be unconstitutional

events.title: LeCompton Constitution
events.description: proposed constitution for the state of Kansas during territorial disputes over slavery; wanted to establish Kansas as a slave state but became symbol of failure regarding expansion of slavery

events.title: Panic of 1857
events.description: North was heavily invested in industries that caused the panic but the South were more reliant on shipping and foreign economy; emboldened South that slavery was good for economy and made a false sense of security that they would succeed as a country

events.title: Lincoln-Douglas Debates
events.description: a series of seven debates between Abraham Lincoln and Stephen A. Douglas mostly on the extension of slavery into new territories; Lincoln prompted moral issues of slavery, while Douglas promoted popular sovereignty; Douglas won reelection to senate but Lincoln gained national recognition

events.title: Freeport Doctrine
events.description: asserted that territories could effectively exclude slavery by not adopting laws to protect it

events.title: 'a house divided against itself cannot stand
events.description: Lincoln emphasized that unity was essential and nation could not be permanently half slave and half free; after Lincoln's election, many Southerners believed their way of life was under threat

events.title: John Brown's Raid on Harpers Ferry
events.description: armed attack by John Brown to seize federal armory and spark a slave uprising; Brown was captured during the raid and tried for treason against Virginia, and was executed on December 2nd

events.title: Crittenden Compromise
events.description: unsuccessful proposal to make it unconstitutional for future congress to end slavery

events.title: Lincoln elected
events.description: Lincoln defeats Douglas (Dem), but not on a abolitionist stance

events.title: Civil War
events.description: debates over slavery caused Southern succession and war between Union (North) and Confederates (South)

events.title: 'necessity knows no law'
events.description: Lincoln increases army and navy, creates first income tax, creates greenbacks, removes freedom of press or speech

events.title: Confederacy established
events.description: Davis as president, weak government as many Southerners disliked strong government; no protective tariffs, no federal funded improvements, states could impeach federal officers, state supreme, protection of slavery, and 2/3 of house to appropriate money

events.title: Kansas admitted as a free state
events.description: anti-slavery forces in Kansas was more significant

events.title: Ex Parte Marryman
events.description: Lincoln suspends habeas corpus (allowed detention of individuals) and passes martial law in Maryland

events.title: Battle of Bull Run
events.description: South victory ends up extending the Civil War

events.title: Pacific Railroad Act
events.description: partially federally funded railroad and gave land for railroad; received little resistance as the South had seceded

events.title: Homestead Act
events.description: government land grants for agricultural college to promote agricultural growth

events.title: Battle of Antietam
events.description: aftermath led Lincoln to issue Emancipation Proclamation, changing focus of war to include slavery and dissuaded Britain and France from recognizing the Confederacy

events.title: Banking Acts
events.description: established federally chartered banks; was possible due to little resistance of the South that had seceded

events.title: Draft Riot in New York
events.description: over unfair burden of poor as rich could get out of drafts; significant violence, particularly of working-class Irish immigrants, fearing their jobs would be taken by freed African Americans if they were conscripted

events.title: Emancipation Proclamation
events.description: declared that all persons held as slaves in rebellious states to be free

events.title: Battle of Gettysburg
events.description: turning point to Union strength in war; largest number of casualties in th entire war, where Robert E. Lee of the Confederates made an ambitious quest to invade the north but was cut down

events.title: '10 Percent Plan'
events.description: Lincoln proposed a reconstruction program that would allow the Southern states to be readmitted once ten percent of its voters took an oath of allegiance to the Union; offered a lenient path for reestablishment and reconciliation

events.title: Lincoln is reelected
events.description: defeats McClellan (Dem), a previous officer who had worked under Lincoln but was fired multiple times after failures

events.title: Wade-Davis Bill
events.description: divided South ito military units until majority pledges allegiance and bans slavery; with Wade-Davis Manifesto that suggested Congress controlled reconstruction

events.title: Sand Creek Massacre
events.description: Chivington attacks defenseless Indian village, many of whom wre women and children; highlights violet conflicts and culture tensions during westward expansion

events.title: Civil War ends
events.description: Civil War effectively ended as Confederate General Robert E. Lee surrendered to Union General Ulysses s. Grant at Appomattox Court House in Virginia; firmly demonstrated the strength of the U.S. government and restored legitimacy to handle sectional tensions

events.title: Freedmen's Bureau
events.description: federal agency to assist newly freed slaves in the South after the Civil War by providing food, housing, education, and medical care; Souther whites resisted its policies and undermined its authority with violence and intimidation

events.title: Andrew Johnson becomes president
events.description: Lincoln is assassinated at Ford's Theatre by John Wilkes Booth, becoming the first president to be assassinated in office; led many to blame South who were bitter of loss

events.title: Johnson's amnesty plan
events.description: pardons almost all Confederates who had directly or indirectly taken part in the rebellion and restored all rights of property except slaves

events.title: Thirteenth Amendment
events.description: formally abolishes slavery in its entirety, even in the North

units.summary: Economic and demographic shifts of the nation, settlement in the West, the "New South," reform movements, and debates about government role

presidents.name: Andrew Johnson
presidents.description: Led through black rights movements and KKK

presidents.name: Ulysses S. Grant
presidents.description: Made successful foreign policy and improved Anglo-American relations

presidents.name: Rutherford B. Hayes
presidents.description: Brought forth the Gilded Age

presidents.name: James A. Garfield
presidents.description: Assassinated

presidents.name: Chester A. Arthur
presidents.description: Expansion of the U.S. Navy, end of the spoils system, and harsher immigration restrictions

presidents.name: Grover Cleveland
presidents.description: Period of unrest with labor unions

events.title: Declaration of Dependence
events.description: Articulated the principle of individual liberty and government's responsibility to serve the government's economy

units.summary: America's changing society and culture, imperialism and global policy during the two wars, innovations, and combatting domestic problems

presidents.name: Benjamin Harrison
presidents.description: Played into foreign affairs and westward expansion

presidents.name: Grover Cleveland
presidents.description: First non-consecutive president, dealt with more labor unions

presidents.name: William McKinley
presidents.description: Imperialistic policies with overseas and domestic intentions

presidents.name: Theodore Roosevelt
presidents.description: Imperialism in the Americas and Latin America

presidents.name: William H. Taft
presidents.description: Income tax and tariffs

presidents.name: Woodrow Wilson
presidents.description: Led the United States through minimal foreign intervention of World War I

presidents.name: Warren G. Harding
presidents.description: Return to normalcy after World War I

presidents.name: Calvin Coolidge
presidents.description: Anti-immigration

presidents.name: Herbert Hoover
presidents.description: Attempting to bring the U.S. through the Great Depression

presidents.name: Franklin D. Roosevelt
presidents.description: Brought the Era of Reform through the New Deal and guided the U.S. through World War II

presidents.name: Harry S. Truman
presidents.description: Ended World War II

events.title: Declaration of Dependence
events.description: Articulated the principle of individual liberty and government's responsibility to serve the government's economy

units.summary: U.S. rivalry with the Soviet Union and the expansion of communism, spread of youth culture, and civil rights movements

presidents.name: Harry S. Truman
presidents.description: Post World War II foreign policy and combatting spread of communism

presidents.name: Dwight D. Eisenhower
presidents.description: Cold War policies

events.title: Declaration of Dependence
events.description: Articulated the principle of individual liberty and government's responsibility to serve the government's economy
